Line 346: Line 346:
===Bahrain===
===Bahrain===
â
[[File:Thousands of demonstrators gather for "National demands An elected government" rally in Karrana, Bahrain.jpg|thumb|Thousands of demonstrators gather for "National demands: An elected government" rally in Karrana, Bahrain on July, 8]]
 
{{main|2011 Bahraini uprising}}
{{main|2011 Bahraini uprising}}
  +
[[File:Thousands of demonstrators gather for "National demands An elected government" rally in Karrana, Bahrain.jpg|thumb|Thousands of demonstrators gather for "National demands: An elected government" rally in Karrana, Bahrain on July, 8]]
The 2011 protests in [[Bahrain]] were initially aimed at achieving greater [[political freedom]] and respect for [[human rights in Bahrain|human rights]], and were not intended to threaten the monarchy.<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb">{{Cite news|title=Clashes mark Bahrain 'Day of Rage'|date=14 February 2011|publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011214925802473.html|accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Lingering frustration among the Shiite majority with being ruled by the Sunni government was a major root cause, but the protests in Tunisia and Egypt are cited as the inspiration for the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news|title=wo Protesters Dead as Bahrain Declares State of Emergency|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/16/world/middleeast/16bahrain.html?scp=43&sq=bahrain%20majority&st=cse|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=11 May 2011|work=The New York Times|first=Ethan|last=Bronner}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Forces Rout Protesters From Bahrain Square|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/17/world/middleeast/17bahrain.html?scp=1&sq=bahrain%20majority&st=cse|date=16 March 2011|accessdate=11 May 2011|work=The New York Times|first=Ethan|last=Bronner|title=Bahrain Troops Oust Protesters From Square}}</ref> The protests began in Bahrain on 14 February<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb"/> and were largely peaceful, until a raid by police on the night of 17 February against protestors sleeping at the [[Pearl Roundabout]] in [[Manama]], in which police killed three protestors.<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb">{{Cite news|first=|last=|pages=|language=|title=Clashes rock Bahraini capital|date=2011-02|publisher=Al Jazeera English |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |accessdate=17 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wZPVZfFG|archivedate=17 February 2011|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="bbc231injured">{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12490286|title=Bahrain protests: Police break up Pearl Square crowd|author=[[BBC]]|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=17 February 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Following the deadly raid, the protestors' aims expanded to a call for the end of the [[King of Bahrain|monarchy]].<ref name="guard_downwiththeking">{{Cite news|first=|last=|pages=|language=|title=Bahrain mourners call for end to monarchy |date=18 February 2011 |publisher=The Guardian/[[Associated Press|AP]] |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-mourners-call-downnfall-monarchy|accessdate=18 February 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5waOzlomm |archivedate=18 February 2011 |deadurl=no |location=London}}</ref> On 18 February, government forces opened fire on protesters, mourners, and news journalists,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/19/world/middleeast/19bahrain.html?src=tptw|work=The New York Times |first1=Michael |last1=Slackman |first2=Nadim |last2=Audi |title=Security Forces in Bahrain Open Fire on Protesters|date=18 February 2011}}</ref> prompting protesters to begin calling for the overthrow of the Bahraini monarchy and government.<ref>{{cite web|author=Posted: Friday, 18 February 2011 |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2011/02/18/2071426/protesters-dig-in-after-bahrains.html|title=Protesters dig in after Bahrain's army opens fire|publisher=CharlotteObserver.com|date=19 May 2008|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> On 19 February, protesters occupied Pearl Square after the government ordered troops and police to withdraw.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Kevin Connolly|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12514849|title=Bahrain unrest: Protesters reoccupy Pearl Square|publisher=BBC|date=20 February 2011|accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12515906|title=Day of transformation in Bahrain's 'sacred square'|publisher=BBC News|date=19 February 2011|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://online.wsj.com/video/protesters-retake-pearl-square-in-bahrain/891AE263-8831-4E00-AC4A-6A49EC09691F.html?mod=WSJ_Article_Videocarousel_3 |title=Protesters Retake Pearl Square in Bahrain |work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> On 22 February, an estimated one hundred thousand people, one fifth of the nation's population, marched. On 14 March, at the request of the Crown Prince, [[Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf|GCC]] Saudi Arabian troops entered the country,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/14/us-bahrain-protests-forces-idUSLDE72D0KH20110314 | work=Reuters | title=Saudi sends troops, Bahrain Shi'ites call it "war" | date=14 March 2011}}</ref> and opened fire on the protesters, several of whom were killed.<ref>[http://www.rediff.com/news/report/baharain-troops-open-fire-kill-two/20110316.htm Bahrain troops open fire on protestors; 2 killed â Rediff.com India News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/three-killed-as-troops-open-fire-in-bahrain/story-e6frg6so-1226022758401 Three killed as troops open fire in Bahrain | The Australian<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Later thousands of [[2011 Iraqi protests|Shia protesters]] arose in Iraq and [[Qatif]] in opposition to the [[Peninsula Shield Force|Saudi-led]] intervention in Bahrain.<ref>al-Ansary, Khalid (16 March 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/16/us-bahrain-iraq-idUSTRE72F4U220110316 "Iraq's Sadr Followers March Against Bahrain Crackdown"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref><ref>[[Staff writer]] (2 April 2011). [http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5igs1wV4hAVspBksbBZq7St89ViQQ?docId=0c4b1a5364514628baec418f05c59a7f "Crackdown in Bahrain Enflames Iraq's Shiites"]. [[Associated Press]] (via [[Google News]]). Retrieved 15 April 2011.</ref><ref>{{registration required|date=April 2011}} {{cite news | author = Arango, Tim | title = Shiites in Iraq Support Bahrain's Protesters | work = [[The New York Times]] | date=2 April 2011 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02iraq.html}}</ref>
The 2011 protests in [[Bahrain]] were initially aimed at achieving greater [[political freedom]] and respect for [[human rights in Bahrain|human rights]], and were not intended to threaten the monarchy.<ref name="JazeeraBah14Feb">{{Cite news|title=Clashes mark Bahrain 'Day of Rage'|date=14 February 2011|publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011214925802473.html|accessdate=14 February 2011}}</ref> Lingering frustration among the Shiite majority with being ruled by the Sunni government was a major root cause, but the protests in Tunisia and Egypt are cited as the inspiration for the demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news|title=wo Protesters Dead as Bahrain Declares State of Emergency|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/16/world/middleeast/16bahrain.html?scp=43&sq=bahrain%20majority&st=cse|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=11 May 2011|work=The New York
